author: By Matt Phillips
title: Banks Are Bingeing on Bonds, but Not Because They Want To
description: Banks are awash in deposits, and their customers are taking out fewer loans. So they have little choice but to buy up government debt, even if it means skimpy profits.
content: The economy is growing. Businesses are hiring. Stocks are marching ever higher. And banks are sitting on big piles of cash.

title: Interview With Kathy Hochul: ‘I Feel a Heavy Weight of Responsibility’

content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Governor Kathy C. Hochul, the first woman in history to lead New York, took the helm this week under extraordinary circumstances, as she replaced a disgraced governor and moved to confront staggering public health, educational and economic challenges across the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: House Panel Demands Records of Trump’s Movements on Jan. 6
description: The request was part of a far-reaching set of documents the select committee sought from seven federal agencies, which suggested the inquiry was focusing on the former president’s role.
content: WASHINGTON — The select committee scrutinizing the Jan. 6 Capitol riot demanded detailed records on Wednesday about Donald J. Trump’s every movement and meeting on the day of the assault, in a series of requests to federal agencies that suggested it was focusing on any ties the former president may have had to the attack’s planning or execution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: A Swimmer’s Journey From Afghanistan to Refugee Camps to the Paralympics

content: TOKYO — The first time Abbas Karimi jumped into a pool, the water brought fresh relief from the heat of Kabul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Teenage Aviator Aims to Be Youngest Woman to Circle the Globe Solo
description: Zara Rutherford, 19, left Belgium last week and plans to complete her journey by early November. Bad weather may be the biggest obstacle.
content: Zara Rutherford, 19, was about 20 minutes into a flight from Iceland to Greenland when her tiny plane lost radio contact with the outside world.

title: Budding Resistance to the Taliban Faces Long Odds
description: For now, the fighters have merely two assets: a narrow valley with a history of repelling invaders and the legacy of a storied mujahedeen commander.
content: The first signs of armed resistance to the Taliban have come from a narrow valley with a history of repelling invaders.

description: School, work and social life are still very much in flux.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: The Uniform Cool of Charlie Watts
description: With his Savile Row suits, custom shirts and jazzman’s assurance, the Rolling Stones drummer staged his own quiet rebellion.
content: “Style is the answer to everything,” Charles Bukowski, of all people, once said in a lecture that’s still afloat in the ether of YouTube. Swigging Schlitz from a bottle, the pockmarked laureate of the underground discoursed on one of the few traits that, as is well known, one may possess though never acquire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Delta steps up pressure on employees to get vaccinated.
description: Unvaccinated workers have to wear masks and will soon have to take weekly coronavirus tests. Eventually, they will have to pay $200 in additional health care costs.
content: Delta Air Lines is intensifying pressure on employees to get vaccinated with a series of increasingly burdensome requirements over the coming weeks and months, though it stopped short of the mandates that other airlines and businesses have put in place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dawn Chan
title: Wong Ping’s Candy-Colored, Taboo-Smashing World
description: His animations make for uncomfortable viewing in an exhibition at the New Museum. But fixating on their shock value misses the point.
content: Wong Ping’s animations give us a glimpse into a strange inner world — a world of hapless and depraved characters caught in a sequence of surreal plot twists.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: NADA x Foreland, where art fair meets group show; and portraits of daily life in Nairobi by the painter Elias Mung’ora.
content: Summer’s not quite over — you’ve still got time for a dash upstate, and this weekend in particular the whole Hudson Valley is in bloom with art. The biggest single event is the New Art Dealer Alliance’s brand-new NADA x Foreland, a kind of art fair meets group show, spearheaded by the curator Jesse Greenberg in a newly rehabilitated complex of Civil-War-era buildings — the titular “Foreland”— in Catskill, N.Y. The idea was essentially to get people out and about again, and the 81 galleries and nonprofits, chosen from an open call, will install their largely sculptural work together, without booths. Though some exhibitors come from as far afield as Bucharest and Vancouver, most are from New York State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Houses of Worship Struggle Back, and Tread Lightly on Vaccines
description: Emptied out by the pandemic, most churches in New York City do not require worshipers to be vaccinated. Rules vary from place to place.
content: The weekly rhythms of Catholic life have started to return at Our Lady of Lourdes in Harlem. The pews are packed on Sunday mornings, prayer groups meet after work and the collection plate is almost as full as it was before the coronavirus pandemic began.

author: By Stephen Wertheim
title: End the Imperial Presidency
description: Congress needs to stop abdicating its constitutional duty to determine whether, where and whom America should fight.
content: Suppose President Biden came before Congress to announce that ending the war in Afghanistan was only the beginning. In recent years, the United States has used force on the ground or conducted strikes from the air in at least nine countries: not only Afghanistan, but also Iraq, Kenya, Libya, Mali, Pakistan, Somalia, Syria and Yemen. These wars go on in part because one person wages them. Congress has abdicated its constitutional duty to determine whether, where and whom America should fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: In First Interview From Jail, an Upbeat Navalny Discusses Prison Life
description: Russian political prisoners today are subjected to “psychological” pressure, said the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, who is forced to watch state TV for more than eight hours a day.
content: MOSCOW — Russia’s most famous prisoner, the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, spends much of his time tidying his cellblock, reading letters and visiting the mess for meals, with porridge often on the menu.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Donald Rumsfeld, Architect of War in Afghanistan, Is Laid to Rest

content: WASHINGTON — A horse-drawn caisson with a flag-draped coffin passed slowly through the gates of Arlington National Cemetery on Monday, a hushed tableau against a city loud with recriminations about the lost war in Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

description: What’s it like to be fame-adjacent? The premise of this dark HBO Max comedy was in some ways familiar territory for its two stars. That may not last.
content: Drew Tarver’s room at the Bowery Hotel was bright. It was comfortable. It overlooked a cemetery, but not in a creepy way. When Tarver arrived, jet-lagged and rain-soaked after a late flight from Los Angeles, he found a Bowery-branded teddy bear on the bed and a bottle of red wine on the cafe table, compliments of the manager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Biden Falls Short on Pledge for U.S. to Be the World’s Vaccine ‘Arsenal,’ Experts Say
description: Congress appropriated $16 billion to ramp up Covid-19 countermeasures, but a new report found that the Biden administration had spent very little of it on expanding vaccine manufacturing capacity.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden, who has pledged to fight the coronavirus pandemic by making the United States the “arsenal of vaccines” for the world, is under increasing criticism from public health experts, global health advocates and even Democrats in Congress who say he is nowhere near fulfilling his promise.

title: Supreme Court Allows Revival of Trump-Era ‘Remain in Mexico’ Asylum Policy
description: The court’s unsigned order refused to stay a ruling from a federal judge in Texas forbidding the Biden administration from ending the policy.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday refused to block a ruling from a federal judge in Texas requiring the Biden administration to reinstate a Trump-era immigration program that forces asylum seekers arriving at the southwestern border to await approval in Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. intelligence agencies delivered a report to Biden on the virus’s origins.
description: The nation’s spy agencies have not yet concluded whether the disease was the result of an accidental leak from a lab or if it emerged naturally in a spillover from animals to humans.
content: The director of national intelligence delivered a report to President Biden on Tuesday on the origins of the coronavirus epidemic, according to U.S. officials, but the nation’s spy agencies have not yet concluded whether the disease was the result of an accidental leak from a lab or if it emerged naturally in a spillover from animals to humans.

title: Pfizer and BioNTech say a third shot boosts antibodies against the virus.
description: The companies said they will submit their data by the end of the week and ask the F.D.A. to approve a third shot.
content: Pfizer and BioNTech said on Wednesday they were now applying to the Food and Drug Administration for supplemental approval of a coronavirus vaccine booster shot for those aged 16 and up, and will submit all their supporting data by the end of this week. The move came as the companies said that a third shot of the vaccine sharply increased the levels of antibodies against the virus.

content: In an interview with The New York Times, the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny discusses life in Penal Colony No. 2 in Pokrov, Russia, where he is being held; President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia; international sanctions imposed on Russia; the upcoming elections for the Duma, Russia’s lower house of Parliament; his poisoning with the chemical weapon Novichok; being tailed by the Federal Security Service, or the F.S.B., the successor agency to the K.G.B.; and a host of other issues. These excerpts have been edited for space and clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 U.S. Representatives Try to Explain Unauthorized Visit to Kabul
description: Representatives Seth Moulton and Peter Meijer said they could not get answers on the evacuation from the Biden administration, so they went to Afghanistan to see for themselves.
content: WASHINGTON — Representatives Seth Moulton, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Peter Meijer, Republican of Michigan, stunned Washington when they secretly flew to Kabul on Tuesday on an unauthorized mission to witness the evacuation of Americans and Afghans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: My Auntie Taught Me the Secret to a Perfect Breakfast: Improvise
description: Upma is a simple, delicious South Indian breakfast dish that you can make differently every time.
content: When I visited my Auntie Sulu in India, she cooked three meals a day and wrote out the plan for each one on a sheet of paper that she kept by the phone in her apartment. The idea of such a plan suggests a certain rigidity, but no, this was a shared, living document. It included, for each meal, the company my auntie expected and the menu, no matter how simple, and it was constantly revised. An edit might become necessary to include someone’s favorite dish; or to make room for a snack we’d forgotten we all wanted but that had come up in conversation; or to add the names of more friends dropping by; or to account for a spontaneous trip to our favorite chaat vendor, which necessitated a later dinner; or for the pile of ripe custard apples someone had brought home, which had to be eaten immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Flowers and Mitchell Bernard
title: When Environmental Racism Causes a Hygienic Hell
description: Mount Vernon is one of scores of cities around the country with an outdated or overtaxed sewage system.
content: Linda McNeil had barely settled into her newly built home a 20-minute drive from Manhattan when raw sewage first flooded her basement. That was 21 years ago, and the problem has only grown worse. Like others among the predominantly Black population in the city of Mount Vernon, N.Y., Ms. McNeil and her family have spent thousands of dollars on equipment to manually pump out the human waste that routinely backs up from the city’s failing wastewater system and gushes into her toilet, bathtub and sink. For months last winter it happened several times a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: When ‘Y Tu Mamá También’ Changed Everything
description: The film, with its sexual openness, upended the lives of its filmmakers and stars. Twenty years later, they still feel the effects.
content: Mexican cinema was just emerging from decades of obscurity when Alfonso Cuarón’s “Y Tu Mamá También,” a voyage of self-discovery and the study of a country in flux, was released there in 2001, instantly achieving landmark status.

title: How 2 Jewish Sisters Built a Cultural Oasis During World War II
description: In “The Sisters of Auschwitz,” a best seller in the Netherlands for more than two years, Roxane van Iperen writes about the way Janny and Lien Brilleslijper staged their own form of resistance.
content: NAARDEN, the Netherlands — Midway through “The Sisters of Auschwitz,” Roxane van Iperen’s book on two Dutch Jewish sisters who aided dozens of people during World War II, there is a moment of merriment that one doesn’t usually expect from a Holocaust narrative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: A 115-Year-Old War Veteran Looks Back at It All, With God as a Guide
description: Robert Olen Butler’s “Late City” is the sentimental story of a man on his deathbed discovering new truths about his life.
content: An elderly person looking back on life is a reliable frame in fiction, and Sam Cunningham, the narrator of Robert Olen Butler’s “Late City,” has an awful lot of life for material. He’s 115 years old, the last surviving veteran of World War I, and he’s dying in a Chicago nursing home bed in the hours after Donald Trump has been elected president.
source.name: The New York Times

title: There’s Still Time to Savor Summer

title: South Dakota Attorney General Will Plead No Contest in Fatal Crash
description: A spokesman said Jason R. Ravnsborg did not plan to resign over the misdemeanor charges, despite calls from both sides of the aisle for him to do so.
content: Jason R. Ravnsborg, the South Dakota attorney general who struck and killed a man while driving home from a Republican Party dinner last year, will plead no contest on Thursday to two misdemeanor charges he faces in connection with the case, his lawyer said on Wednesday.

description: He was an accomplished mountain climber with a literary gift to match, and the author of dozens of books.
content: When David Roberts wrote his first book, a personal account of climbing and death in the mountains of Alaska, more than 50 years ago, he sparked a genre of outdoors writing that still pulses through the publishing world.

title: Lorde Opts Out on the Provocatively Subdued ‘Solar Power’

content: Kate Westrin, a mother of two in Denver, used to commute to the office four days a week for her job as a people experience manager at Xero, a cloud-based accounting software company. author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: New case reports are leveling off globally despite the U.S. surge, the W.H.O. says.
description: Reports of new coronavirus cases around the world are showing signs of flattening, even though they are still rising rapidly in the United States, the World Health Organization said in its latest weekly assessment.
content: Reports of new coronavirus cases around the world are showing signs of flattening, even though they are still rising rapidly in the United States, the World Health Organization said in its latest weekly assessment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Reggie Ugwu
title: Spike Lee Re-Edits HBO Sept. 11 Series That Features Conspiracists
description: An episode of the eight-hour documentary series has drawn criticism for giving a platform to people who have long peddled debunked claims about what caused the towers to collapse.
content: Facing mounting criticism for spotlighting conspiracy theorists in his new HBO documentary series about the Sept. 11 attacks on New York, the filmmaker Spike Lee said Wednesday that he was re-editing the final episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sami Sadat
title: I Commanded Afghan Troops This Year. We Were Betrayed.
description: It pains me to see President Biden and other Western officials blame the Afghan Army for collapsing but not mention why that happened.
content: For the past three and a half months, I fought day and night, nonstop, in southern Afghanistan’s Helmand Province against an escalating and bloody Taliban offensive. Coming under frequent attack, we held the Taliban back and inflicted heavy casualties. Then I was called to Kabul to command Afghanistan’s special forces. But the Taliban already were entering the city; it was too late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: How This Paralympic Archer Found a Bull’s-eye Without an Arrow
description: Lia Coryell often questioned whether life with a debilitating disease was worth living. But then she found a purpose, and it goes way beyond shooting arrows at targets.
content: LA CROSSE, Wis. — From across the archery range, Erich Mueller spotted the woman in the wheelchair wearing a shirt that said, “I Hate Running,” and knew he had to meet her. Stifling a laugh, he introduced himself to Lia Coryell, and she smiled and called him Honey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: ‘1, 2, 3 … Exhale Together’: Broadway Families, Reunited at Last
description: Before the reopenings were the in-person reunions. And hugs. So many hugs. Here’s a look at some of the first emotional moments on the road back.
content: The “Waitress” cast and crew hugged. They embraced. They squeezed. They swayed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Mandatory vaccination of the U.S. military will begin ‘immediately,’ the defense secretary says.
description: Federal approval of Pfizer-BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine on Monday led the Pentagon to mandate the shots for American service members.
content: Mandatory vaccination against the coronavirus for active-duty U.S. service members who have not already gotten shots will begin now, though no hard deadline has been set to complete it, the secretary of defense said in a memo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: The Latest G.O.P. Schism: How to Handle Afghan Evacuees
description: The resettlement of Afghan allies in the U.S. is revealing an internal divide between the party’s anti-immigrant wing and other conservatives who want to help the refugees.
content: WASHINGTON — The Republican Party is united in its criticism of President Biden’s chaotic military withdrawal from Afghanistan. But the crisis has also exposed a deep internal divide between party leaders over relocating Afghan refugees at home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: America Today: Too Much Water, or Not Enough
description: The United States, like most of the planet, is becoming both drier and wetter in the era of climate change. These maps show the divide.
content: The United States, like most of the world, is becoming both drier and wetter. It depends where you live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Former ‘Good Morning America’ Producer Accused of Sexual Assault in Lawsuit
description: Another producer on the show said Michael Corn assaulted her during a work trip to Los Angeles in 2015. He denied the allegation.
content: A producer at the ABC News program “Good Morning America” accused Michael Corn, a former senior executive producer of the show, of sexually assaulting her and creating a toxic work environment in a lawsuit filed Wednesday against Mr. Corn and ABC.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Traci Carl
title: U.S., others warn of threat at airport in Kabul and tell citizens to leave immediately.
description: The U.S. government has long warned of potential security threats but the latest warning cited specific gates.
content: The U.S. Embassy warned Americans to stay away from the Kabul airport and told anyone outside the perimeter to “leave immediately,” citing unnamed security threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: Aretha Franklin and the Futility of Trying to Portray Her Onscreen
description: The new film “Respect” is one of three recent attempts to understand the artist. Only the one that focuses solely on her music comes close.
content: Early on in “Respect,” the latest onscreen retelling of Aretha Franklin’s story, the aging jazz and R&B star Dinah Washington asks her protégée, “Child, are you ever going to tell us who the daddy is?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Drew Taylor
title: Bringing a (Jurassic) World of Star Power to Theme Park Queues
description: Hang out in line at a theme park this summer with Chris Pratt, or at least a video of him.
content: This summer Chris Pratt, Tom Holland and Bryce Dallas Howard are all starring in new productions, financed by major studios and enjoyed by countless viewers. But these projects didn’t debut on movie screens; they’re not streaming worldwide either. Instead, these stars are making a splash on the screens you watch while waiting in the line for new theme park attractions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: ‘Made in Afghanistan’ Once Symbolized Hope. Now It’s Fear.
description: Fashion was seen as a way forward for the country and its craftspeople, especially women. But those involved are terrified it may turn them into targets.
content: Haseeb Rahimi, a 30-year-old Afghan entrepreneur, and his younger sister, Rahiba Rahimi, a designer, had big plans for 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York City Rents Rise, Even as Thousands Struggle to Pay
description: One report found that rents in the city were now the highest in the nation, surpassing San Francisco. At the same time, tens of thousands of people are millions of dollars behind on rent.
content: On her first day in office this week, Gov. Kathy Hochul said that she would move to strengthen New York’s beleaguered effort to distribute pandemic rent relief, highlighting the plight of hundreds of thousands of struggling New Yorkers who are at risk of being evicted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy and Amy Chang Chien
title: Rejecting Covid Inquiry, China Peddles Conspiracy Theories Blaming the U.S.
description: A new wave of disinformation follows President Biden’s order for the United States to investigate the origin of the pandemic, including the possibility of a lab leak in Wuhan.
content: When a conspiracy theory started circulating in China suggesting that the coronavirus escaped from an American military lab, it had largely stayed on the fringe. Now, the ruling Communist Party has propelled the idea firmly into the mainstream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: After a Year Without Fans, U.S. Open Will Welcome a Full House
description: No proof of vaccination or a recent negative coronavirus test will be required for fans to enter the grounds, and no masks will be required when they are outdoors.
content: The U.S. Open welcomed almost 750,000 fans onto its grounds in 2019 during its two-week run, and comparable numbers are expected to attend this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Rand V. Araskog, Former Chief of ITT Corp., Dies at 89
description: Over two decades, during a tumultuous time for American business, he winnowed an unwieldy corporation and fended off corporate raids.
content: Rand V. Araskog, who as chief executive of the ITT Corporation in the 1980s and ’90s successfully refocused an unwieldy conglomerate that at various points ran the Sheraton hotel chain, owned the New York Knicks and Rangers and made Wonder Bread, died on Aug. 9 at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Burge
title: A More Secular America Is Not Just a Problem for Republicans
description: Americans have not yet come to terms with this cultural shift.
content: Since 1988, the General Social Survey has been asking Americans of different ages what they believe about God. For decades, the answer did not change much. Around 70 percent of members of the Silent Generation said that they “know God really exists” and “have no doubts about it.” That same sentiment was shared by about 63 percent of baby boomers and Generation Xers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: Cory Booker Outfoxed Republicans on ‘Defund the Police.’ Now What?
description: He deflected the Republican effort to portray Senate Democrats as radicals on police reform — but can he sell any better ideas?
content: In the 16th hour of a Senate debate earlier this month, Cory Booker rose to speak around 1 a.m. “I am so excited!” he roared, bunching his shoulders and smacking a fist into his hand, like a pitcher trotting to the mound. Booker, who represents New Jersey, leaned back and put a hand into his pocket. He smiled and raised one eyebrow mischievously. “This is a gift,” he declared. “If it wasn’t complete abdication of Senate procedures and esteem, I would walk over there and hug my colleague from Alabama.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: OnlyFans Reverses Its Decision to Ban Explicit Content
description: Many of the platform’s stars felt the sting of being turned away by a business they helped build.
content: It is hard to overstate the degree to which OnlyFans reversed the general downward trajectory of being an adult entertainment performer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Five women on a famed Afghan robotics team arrive in Mexico.
description: Five young women who are part of a famed Afghan robotics team — which had been a symbol of opportunities for women and girls in a post-Taliban Afghanistan — have arrived in Mexico as part of the first group of evacuees to land there.
content: Five young women who are part of a famed Afghan robotics team — which had been a symbol of opportunities for women and girls in a post-Taliban Afghanistan — have arrived in Mexico as part of the first group of evacuees to land there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Sticks to Afghan Deadline, Resisting Pleas to Extend Evacuation
description: The American withdrawal coincided with a threat by the Taliban to stop Afghans from traveling to the airport, an ominous sign that the window may be slamming shut for thousands of people desperate to leave.
content: President Biden said Tuesday that the United States intended to withdraw completely from Afghanistan at the end of the month as planned, rebuffing pleas from Britain, France and other NATO allies to keep troops in Kabul and hastening the end of a frantic evacuation that has become a grim coda to two decades of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: China’s disinformation campaign makes the pandemic’s origins even murkier.
content: It’s been more than 18 months since the first cases of a mysterious “pneumonialike illness” were reported in Wuhan, China. The world still isn’t any closer to understanding how the pandemic started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Inflation Could Stay High Next Year, and That’s OK
description: The Fed has boxed itself into a corner by predicting a rapid decline in inflation in 2022.
content: In life, description should precede prescription. You observe reality (description) and then decide what to do (prescription). Too often, though, people work backward. They start with a judgment and then assemble a version of reality that supports it. To wit, face masks are bad, therefore face masks don’t protect against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden to Campaign for Gov. Newsom Before California Recall Election
description: Some political activists had wondered whether the turmoil in Afghanistan would cause President Biden to back out of a planned trip to help Mr. Newsom retain his job.
content: LOS ANGELES — Although he is mired in a political crisis about the withdrawal from Afghanistan, President Biden still plans to campaign for Gov. Gavin Newsom, who is facing a recall election in California, Mr. Biden’s press secretary said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: Can You Give Yourself an At-Home Face-Lift?
description: Emphatically no, say experts — but there are things you can do to make your skin look better.
content: Raise your hand if you’ve ever pulled your skin taut across your face after glancing at yourself in a mirror — or worse, in the little Zoom box — just to see what you’d look like. Congratulations: You just got an at-home face-lift. For a few seconds, anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Farrell
title: A Ceramist Who Draws on His Craft’s Ancient Global Traditions
description: Matthias Kaiser’s extensive travels, and apprenticeships in Japan, continue to inform his nuanced, stylistically wide-ranging vessels.
content: “I was an incredibly naughty teenager,” says the ceramist Matthias Kaiser, who grew up in the Austrian city of Graz. “One day I just disappeared.” In 1989, at age 19, he sold his car and bought a one-way plane ticket to New York in the hopes of becoming a jazz musician (he played the soprano saxophone) — only for a chance encounter to radically alter his plan. Walking along West Broadway about a year after he arrived, he came across a stall where a group of potters were selling traditional, handcrafted Pennsylvanian ceramics and, though simple, the blue-and-white spongeware vessels captivated him. “I just couldn’t believe they were selling these objects that they had made themselves,” he says. “It blew me away.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Where Are the Borrowers?
description: Awash in deposits and with sluggish demand from borrowers, banks are going on a bond-buying spree.
content: The job of a banker, an old joke goes, can be summed up by the 3-6-3 rule: Gather deposits at 3 percent, lend them out at 6 percent and be on the golf course by 3 p.m. These days, banks pay next to nothing in interest, yet they are awash in deposits. They also offer loans at rock-bottom rates, yet see little demand from borrowers. What are they doing with the money instead? Bingeing on bonds, The Times’s Matt Phillips reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Bob Ross: Happy Accidents, Betrayal & Greed’ Review: No Gloss
description: This documentary on “The Joy of Painting” star focuses on the controversy over who controls his brand and legacy.
content: Bob Ross’s hair was a thing of beauty. When he appeared on “Live! With Regis and Kathie Lee,” Regis Philbin teased him about his Afro, which Ross sweetly admitted might be more nurtured than nature. And photos of Ross as a teenager and then as a young airman rocking a pompadour make clear he always liked a good ’do. This is among the cheerier scenes in the director Joshua Rofé’s “Bob Ross: Happy Accidents, Betrayal & Greed,” a documentary less about Ross’s life than about what happened to his brand in the later years and after his death. Annette and Walt Kowalski, who were Ross’s business partners, are not painted in a flattering light. (The couple declined to participate in the film.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi
title: The W.H.O. will address inequities by making vaccines in Latin America.
description: In a region where some populations have extremely limited access to vaccines, public health agencies are taking control of the means of production.
content: To help address unequal access to Covid-19 vaccines around the world — an issue that “remains the Achilles’ heel” of the pandemic fight —  the World Health Organization is starting a program to manufacture vaccines in Latin America and the Caribbean, Dr. Carissa Etienne, the director of the Pan American Health Organization, said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Elsie Chen
title: China will hold the unvaccinated ‘accountable’ if there are outbreaks.
description: The authorities in at least 12 cities in China have warned residents that those who refuse Covid-19 vaccinations could be punished if they are found to be responsible for spreading outbreaks.
content: The authorities in at least 12 cities in China have warned residents that those who refuse Covid-19 vaccinations could be punished if they are found to be responsible for spreading outbreaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Roger Federer’s Biggest Legacy? It Might Be His Billion-Dollar Brand.
description: Other tennis superstars have built sponsorship empires. But none ever wooed the corporate class as brilliantly as Federer.
content: It was moving day in the California desert, and Roger Federer was up before dawn. We met on the tarmac in Thermal, a short drive from Indian Wells, where Federer had lost the day before in the final of the 2018 BNP Paribas Open to Juan Martín del Potro. Just the previous month, Federer had capped his remarkable late-career surge by reclaiming the No. 1 ranking for the first time in more than five years. At 36, he was the oldest player to hold the spot since the A.T.P. published its first rankings in 1973. But Indian Wells was a rather disappointing sequel. He served for the title against del Potro at 5-4 in the third set and failed to finish him off despite holding three match points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: He Sold Antiquities for Decades, Many of Them Fake, Investigators Say
description: The owner of a Manhattan gallery was charged with grand larceny and other crimes by prosecutors who say he mass-produced objects that he passed off as ancient artifacts.
content: For years, looted antiquities have been a law enforcement priority, not only because the smuggling of ancient artifacts damages the cultural heritage of their countries of origin, but because illicit sales have sometimes financed the operation of drug gangs or terror organizations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Extra Shots from J. & J. and Pfizer Give Immune Boost, Companies Report
description: The Food and Drug Administration will evaluate the new data as the Biden administration pushes a booster shot strategy.
content: As vaccine makers set their sights on boosters, new studies unveiled on Wednesday from Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer-BioNTech demonstrated that extra shots can dramatically raise antibodies against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Many Californians Don’t Know There’s a Recall. That’s Not Good for Newsom.
description: The special election is set for Sept. 14.
content: PALMDALE — The light was fading on what had been a breezy 101-degree afternoon by the time the two women with clipboards approached Ashley Reyes, who sat watching her son and his cousins play in her gated driveway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Offices Dangle Beehives and Garden Plots to Coax Workers Back
description: The latest perks include harvesting honey and digging in the dirt, part of a growing effort to give employees access to fresh air, sunlight and plants.
content: The investment company Nuveen has spent $120 million renovating its office tower at 730 Third Avenue in Midtown Manhattan, overhauling the lobby, devoting the second floor to amenities and refurbishing a 22nd-floor terrace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: House Hunting in Mexico: A Playa del Carmen Beach House for $750,000
description: Traditionally a buyer’s market, the city of Playa del Carmen is seeing longstanding inventory get snapped up in a pandemic frenzy.
content: This four-bedroom, four-bath home sits inside the gated resort community of Playacar, in the city of Playa del Carmen, on the east coast of Mexico’s Yucatán Peninsula. Built in 2000 and gradually upgraded, the stone and cement house combines many local materials and architectural features, including palapa roof coverings, made of dried palm fronds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Video Shows Louisiana Trooper Beating a Black Man With a Flashlight
description: The trooper, Jacob Brown, who was charged with assaulting Aaron Larry Bowman in May 2019 and later resigned, defended the attack as “pain compliance.”
content: Body-camera footage publicly emerged on Wednesday showing a Louisiana State Police trooper repeatedly clubbing a Black man on the head and chest with a flashlight while the man was pinned to the ground after a traffic stop in 2019, in what the white trooper called “pain compliance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $320,000 Homes in Pennsylvania, Tennessee and Rhode Island
description: An A-frame vacation home in the Poconos, a three-bedroom house in Chattanooga and a two-bedroom condominium in Providence.
content: The owner of a real estate investment company bought this house in the Pocono Mountains restored it and furnished it to evoke the summer of 1969, the year it was built. For an additional $12,500, he will sell it outfitted with its camp-style décor, down to the martini glasses, birch-bark lamps, Battleship board game and Adirondack chairs around the firepit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum, Nicole Sperling and Julia Jacobs
title: He’s No Longer Host. But Mike Richards Is Still Running ‘Jeopardy!’
description: Defying a backlash over sexist and crude comments, a top Sony TV executive told the show’s staff that the studio stood behind Mr. Richards as the executive producer.
content: Last week, Mike Richards lost his gig as the new host of “Jeopardy!,” faced a rebuke from the Anti-Defamation League, heard an outpouring of dismay from the show’s demoralized staff, and was forced to apologize after it was revealed he made sexist and crude jokes on a podcast several years ago in which he mocked women’s appearances, unemployed workers and the size of Jewish noses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Buy or Wait? Here’s a Guide to Phone Upgrades.
description: Apple, Samsung and others want us to replace our phones constantly, but many of our problems with current devices can be fixed.
content: It’s almost phone season again — the time of year when tech companies like Apple, Google and Samsung bombard us with glitzy marketing campaigns to persuade us to upgrade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: Deflecting an Asteroid Before It Hits Earth May Take Multiple Bumps
description: After years of shooting meteorites with a special gun owned by NASA, researchers highlighted challenges for a preferred method of planetary defense.
content: There’s probably a large space rock out there, somewhere, that has Earth in its cross hairs. Scientists have in fact spotted one candidate — Bennu, which has a small chance of banging into our planet in the year 2182. But whether it’s Bennu or another asteroid, the question will be how to avoid a very unwelcome cosmic rendezvous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Michael LaForgia
title: ‘They Were Bullies’: Inside the Turbulent Origins of the Collapsed Florida Condo
description: The team that developed Champlain Towers managed to build the condos despite checkered pasts, internal strife and a last-minute change that infuriated leaders in Surfside, Fla.
content: It was in the middle of summer in 1980 when developers raising a pair of luxury condominium towers in Surfside, Fla., went to town officials with an unusual request: They wanted to add an extra floor to each building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Noah Weiland
title: Heart Problem More Common After Covid-19 Than After Vaccination, Study Finds
description: The research did not assess the risks specifically for young males, who are the most likely to develop the rare side effect.
content: The Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine is associated with an increased risk of myocarditis, an inflammation of the heart muscle, a large new study from Israel confirms. But the side effect remains rare, and Covid-19 is more likely to cause myocarditis than the vaccine is, scientists reported on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor, Norimitsu Onishi and Sharif Hassan
title: As world leaders craft strategies, Afghans endure an arduous transition.
description: As President Biden navigates the thorny domestic and international politics of meeting an Aug. 31 withdrawal deadline from Afghanistan, and as Taliban leaders keep the world guessing about how they intend to govern, Afghans are enduring a terrifying transitional period: Hundreds of thousands of people fear for their lives, feeding families is becoming more difficult and countless people are afraid to appear in public.
content: As President Biden navigates the thorny domestic and international politics of meeting an Aug. 31 withdrawal deadline from Afghanistan, and as Taliban leaders keep the world guessing about how they intend to govern, Afghans are enduring a terrifying transitional period: Hundreds of thousands of people fear for their lives, feeding families is becoming more difficult and countless people are afraid to appear in public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: A Squalid Border Camp Finally Closed. Now Another One Has Opened.
description: President Biden’s policies helped shut down a camp in Mexico that housed migrants during the Trump administration. But thousands are gathered now in a new camp. “The border is not really any different,” said a lawyer working there.
content: REYNOSA, Mexico — For nearly three years under the Trump administration, a makeshift camp of migrants from all over the world operated in the Mexican city of Matamoros. It was effectively the first refugee camp on the U.S.-Mexico border, packed with people hoping to win asylum in the United States but forced to wait in Mexico while their cases were being considered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Defendant in Plot to Kidnap Michigan Governor Is Sentenced to Six Years
description: Ty G. Garbin, 25, had pleaded guilty to taking part in an extremist plot driven by anger at the governor’s efforts to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
content: The only defendant to plead guilty to taking part in a plot to kidnap Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan was sentenced on Wednesday to six years and three months in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Judge Orders Sanctions Against Pro-Trump Lawyers Over Election Lawsuit
description: Sidney Powell, L. Lin Wood and seven other lawyers deceived federal courts and debased the judicial process, a federal judge wrote.
content: A federal judge in Michigan on Wednesday night ordered sanctions to be levied against nine pro-Trump lawyers, including Sidney Powell and L. Lin Wood, ruling that a lawsuit laden with conspiracy theories that they filed last year challenging the validity of the presidential election was “a historic and profound abuse of the judicial process.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Fallon: Americans Care More About New ‘Spider-Man’ Than Covid’s Origins
description: “In the trailer, Spider-Man visits Dr. Strange and asks him to turn back time. Then President Biden shows up and asks for the same thing,” Fallon joked on Tuesday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Musinguzi Blanshe
title: Uganda takes in evacuees from Afghanistan, honoring a U.S. request.
description: At least 51 people who fled from Afghanistan landed in Uganda on Wednesday, the authorities said, the first to arrive in an African nation amid the race to complete such evacuations before the United States withdraws its military from Afghanistan by the month’s end.
content: At least 51 people who fled from Afghanistan landed in Uganda on Wednesday, the authorities said, the first to arrive in an African nation amid the race to complete such evacuations before the United States withdraws its military from Afghanistan by the month’s end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien and Austin Ramzy
title: Chinese Citizen Who Documented Wuhan Outbreak Falls Ill in Prison Hunger Strike
description: Zhang Zhan was sentenced to four years for videos about failures in handling the virus. She now weighs less than 90 pounds, her former lawyer says.
content: A Chinese citizen journalist who was imprisoned for exposing the failures of the government’s initial response to the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan is seriously ill from a hunger strike, according to messages from her family shared by her former lawyer and a friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane
title: Biden, Needing a Win, Enters a Sprint for His Economic Agenda
description: As his poll numbers slide, the president and his aides have mounted an aggressive pitch in Congress and around the country for his spending plans on infrastructure and more.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden, his aides and his allies in Congress face a September sprint to secure a legislative victory that could define his early presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac, Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
title: Facebook Said to Consider Forming an Election Commission
description: The social network has contacted academics to create a group to advise it on thorny election-related decisions, said people with knowledge of the matter.
content: Facebook has approached academics and policy experts about forming a commission to advise it on global election-related matters, said five people with knowledge of the discussions, a move that would allow the social network to shift some of its political decision-making to an advisory body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Makiko Inoue
title: A Roller Coaster in Japan Shuts Down After Riders Report Broken Bones
description: One of the world’s fastest roller coasters was closed after four passengers in the past nine months reported bone fractures.
content: Looping in view of Mount Fuji, the Do-Dodonpa roller coaster in Japan has been one of the prized fixtures of the Fuji-Q Highland Park since the ride opened in 2001.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Untold: Caitlyn Jenner’ Review: Honoring the Athlete
description: Caitlyn Jenner recalls her past as a decathlon champion in this sports documentary directed by Crystal Moselle.
content: Caitlyn Jenner is best known as a tabloid celebrity and family member of the Kardashian clan who publicly transitioned as a transgender woman. But “Untold: Caitlyn Jenner” — an episode of the new Netflix documentary series “Untold” that highlights underappreciated stories from sports — illuminates the events that brought Jenner her first taste of international recognition; namely, her gold medal win as a decathlon athlete in the 1976 Montreal Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthieu Aikins and Jim Huylebroek
title: The Taliban wants to forget the past, a leader tells The Times, but there will be some restrictions.
description: He was once a faceless spokesman for an insurgent group. On Wednesday, Zabihullah Mujahid, a top Taliban official, held forth in the seat of government.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — In his first sit-down interview with a Western media outlet since the Taliban took full control of Afghanistan, one of the group’s leaders on Wednesday offered a portrait of a group intent on rebuilding a country shattered by decades of war.

author: By Melina Delkic

content: As a wedding photographer, Loreto Caceres was too focused on her clients’ postponements to worry about rescheduling her own nuptials, which were originally slated for January 2021 in Puerto Rico. “I was just over thinking about my own wedding, so we put it off and put it off,” she said. title: How Exercise May Help Keep Our Memory Sharp
description: Irisin, a hormone produced by muscles during exercise, can enter the brain and improve cognition, a mouse study suggests.
content: An intriguing new study shows how exercise may bolster brain health. The study was in mice, but it found that a hormone produced by muscles during exercise can cross into the brain and enhance the health and function of neurons, improving thinking and memory in both healthy animals and those with a rodent version of Alzheimer’s disease. Earlier research shows that people produce the same hormone during exercise, and together the findings suggest that moving could alter the trajectory of memory loss in aging and dementia.

title: 13 Delicious Drinks for Late-Summer Sipping
description: Cocktails, coffees and every beveragino in between for all of your imbibing needs.
content: Did someone say beveragino? At its simplest, a beveragino is a cocktail enjoyed among friends. (The term was popularized last summer by British TikTokers — and cleverly deployed by a group of cheeky ladies hanging out in a garden.) But a beveragino can also be a coffee, a tea, a limeade or a mocktail. Much like life, a beveragino is what you make of it. Ultimately, what may distinguish a beveragino from a beverage is a certain kind of effortless upgrade: not just a cold brew, but a cold brew with a sweet-salty cream cap; not just any old tequila cocktail, but one that’s part Negroni, part spritz. With that in mind, here are 13 beveragino recipes — drinks that are creamy and cooling, fizzy and boozy, tart and refreshing — perfect for your morning scrolling, your evening happy hours and everything in between.
